page.title: 12Local History
page.content: Truro is mentioned in the original 1086 Domesday Book, as Great Truro and Little Truro. The Norman Earls of Cornwall built a castle, but it was probably only a wooden structure and did not last long. The site is still called Castle Hill. In the Civil War the town was a Royalist stronghold until forced to surrender to Fairfax in 1646. Truro's heyday was in the 18th Century, when it was a centre of mining in the County. It had the Stannary Court and Parliament, the miners' regulatory bodies. There is a fine legacy of Georgian architecture from this period; Lemon Street is the finest West of Bath. Richard Lander, the famous explorer of the River Niger was born here. Local newspapers like the West Briton, dating from the 18th Century may be read in the Museum. The County Record Office is also in Truro.
